thread.title: New child booster seat laws are NOW in force - what every parent needs to know
thread.title_full: New child booster seat laws are NOW in force - what every parent needs to know

author: mirror
title: New child booster seat laws are NOW in force - what every parent needs to know
text:
Parents are being urged to check their car booster seats under a safety crackdown (stock photo) (Photo: Getty) Share     
New laws for child car booster cushions have come into force earlier than expected. 
The guidelines, which affect the manufacture of new booster cushions, were expected to be introduced on March 1 but have now been implemented. 
They mean cushions now must be designed to be used by children 22kg or more in weight or at least 125cm tall. 
Laws banning car booster seats without a back rest were revealed in 2016. 
The changes to the rules were delayed until this year. A child car booster seat Read More Cheap high back booster seats under £35 that will keep your child safe under the new laws, plus get 20% off at Halfords 
It is imperative that parents across Lincolnshire make sure their child's seats meet the new regulations. 
However, parents who have already bought a seat before the changes come into force will be allowed to continue to use them, Lincolnshire Live reports. 
At the moment youngsters weighing as little as 15kg (2.4 stone) - normally aged around three years old - are allowed to travel in cars in a backless booster seat. Read More Child booster seat ban: This crash footage shows why you should change your kid's car seat 
However, experts warned this type of seat was unsuitable for smaller children. 
They claimed the adult seat belt isn't guided across their small body in the best way, and a booster seat offers no protection for a child if a car is involved in a side-impact crash. 
If you ignore the law you are liable to a fined £500 if you end up in court. Top tips on what to look for when choosing a car seat for your child: 
1. High back;
